utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hi, everyone. Happy birthday, America. I'm Juan Williams along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Jesse Watters, Dana Perino, and my pal, Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." Welcome to our Independence Day special. We'll have a very fun show here on The Five. We're answering all of your fan mail questions from social media on this Fourth of July. So, let's not waste any more time and get right to it. Our very first question, it comes from Ronald Buckbowers, and it says if you could go back to the first Independence Day, which founding father would you hang out with, Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, let's see. I don't know. I guess one of my favorites always is John Adams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, because, I think, he's just historically very significant. I think that, you know, people more recently have come to understand his value, his influence and how important he was in American political history, some of his ideals, and also his wife. I think they were quite a powerful pair.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The wife?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Of John Adams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it's true. And also, I think, there're two Adams presidents, right?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's pretty cool. Jesse?

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I thought you're going to say Sam Adams.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, that's your choice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would say Ben Franklin because I'm a Philly guy and he's a big influence out in Philadelphia. He's laid to rest there, also a real renaissance man, like myself. A musician, a prolific writer, discovered electricity, so we've had a lot in common on that front. And then, poor Richard's almanac, very inspiring quotes about work and life and I enjoy that. I'd like to hang with Ben.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's cool. And I bet you share humility.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thanks, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm used to the sarcasm there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dana, where would you be hanging out?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I like George Washington. I've always admired him. Plus, he wrote rules of civility. Remember all of those rules you have to follow.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Good choice.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I'm going to ask about that cherry tree.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what's interesting about your answer, I don't think he was married, right? Not for the longest time. Martha comes along, but for the longest time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know when he got married, but they were married.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you saying she wants to hang out with.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: . the father of our country because he wasn't preoccupied with a lot of family.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, he's a busy guy. Lot on his mind. Lot on his mind.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Indeed. Our founding father at this very table, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I'd have to say Bob Lutz. He's the unknown founding father. Nobody talks about Bob, but he was there every step of the way. Bob Lutz. You don't know Bob Lutz?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I rest my case. Actually, I have to say, I find this whole question sexist. Aren't we done with the whole idea of founding fathers? What about founding mothers? What about the founding mothers?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What about founding founders?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Founding founders. And why are we recognizing gender anyway with our founding fathers? Disgusting. It's so heteronormative.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Are you going back to the purple penguin thing?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think I'd hang out with you, guys, with Ben and you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because, I mean, Ben is in the newspaper business, you know?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Right. So, I would like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was a partier. He had two beds in his bedroom because he gets tired when the bed was warm, and so he'd get up and move to the other bed because it was cool.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It sounds like you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, definitely.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He needed one of those beds with the temperature control.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You need a king size.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Beer, barbecue, and fireworks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fireworks. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm going to say dogs. No, I don't know. I like hanging out being with everybody. I like to go to the parade. Wherever I am, I like a small town parade, big town parade, but usually small time parade is really good. And, lately, because Peter has the Harley with the sidecar and then Jasper can get in it and all the kids love that. So, I like the morning of the Fourth of July, even better than fireworks.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow. Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I don't like fireworks. I'm like a dog. They scare me. And I don't like parades because I'm short and I can't see over people. But I'm going to be honest with.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You can get on my shoulders

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know, I know. People will talk. I'm going to be honest, I'm actually not here. I'm not here. I'm celebrating the Fourth of July the way I would like to. Right now, I'm sitting on an island. I'm not going to tell you what island, but I'm sitting on an island right now. This is a taped show.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, excellent. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK. Well, I'm like Dana, I love a good parade. I also really enjoy Dana's Fourth of July posts and pictures.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're pretty good lately.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They've been very strong, so I love it. Really just like celebrating our nation, our independence, our liberty, our freedom, and I think it's great when people come together and go into parade. I'm in to that, the whole deal to commemorate it and, you know, take a moment because all have such busy lives to never forget, you know, the sacrifices that people made so that we can sit here today and have this show and speak our minds, and it's fantastic. It's amazing, most wonderful country in the world.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, my favorite is to find a high spot in Washington D.C. to watch the fireworks. But the one I remember most is being in Boston, and watching the Boston Pops play as the fireworks were going off over Boston. I thought that was spectacular. Who's that? Arthur -- I forget the name of the famous conductor. Anyway.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Fiedler.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Arthur Fiedler.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It was unbelievable. And the other thing I like about the Fourth of July is just -- it's an opportunity to do fireworks. And, so, fireworks, when I was a kid, mostly illegal, but everybody would bring on these trash cans and these big boom, boom, boom. I love that stuff.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Best place to see fireworks right now? My hot tub.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute, I thought you were on an island.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, I'm in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're in, you're in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: How about out west, they do fireworks out in the rain? PERINO: They do well -- some years, because it's so dry out there that they like to have fireworks in case -- starts a wild fire. So, sometimes we would just get those little snakes, the sparklers that's usually the extent of the fireworks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's really lame.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Weakest type of fireworks. You've got to get the roman candles. Those are the way to go, or the M-80's.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm against roman candles. Cultural appropriation.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Here's the third question from Cindy, Carol, Allan, Carly, what traditions did you have for the Fourth of July when you were children? So let's go back this way. Kimberly?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, sure. Well, my brother and I used to really love to do the fireworks, and so it was a big -- it was really fun to be able to go and shop for the -- what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Never mind.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We did. We've love it. And then -- ignore him. Spoiler alert. And so, I loved that. So we would do that and go pick up the fireworks. So it was like a family tradition to go and get them ahead of time. We do a whole thing on the block to, you know, do the fireworks to invite everybody to come. And then, my dad had to sweep up the streets after to clean up the fireworks. And then my brother would stockpile them and the fire department came and we got in trouble.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's a rarity for you as a kid to get in trouble.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, it was mostly due to my brother.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I did the same thing, fireworks were illegal in Philadelphia, so we'd have to go to Chinatown, or way across state lines, somewhere else, and then bring them across and then light them. And I'd do it with my dad, and I still have all my fingers, so safety first.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Safety first. I'm glad to hear that. I think there's a New York Times football player who could have used that lesson.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I remember that we would do a family baseball game or a softball game and have a picnic, but that was always a big deal.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What position would you play?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't really remember. It was more like -- they were kind of serious about it, the adults.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They'd probably stick you out in right field.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's a ditch, just so you know.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We use to do something called fireworks. You guys heard about that? Yeah, we go and get some fireworks. You know what's always the best part it was going shopping because you would always have to go to these stands by your school and you'd either have to buy, like, you wanted the big box, and the big box had all that stuff in it, but you weren't sure if you had all the right stuff, so then you'd fight and all of a sudden it just got ban.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do they have fireworks in California or is it too patriotic?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. It's -- we used to have them and then they took them away. Like they've taken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Global warming, probably.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I've got to tell you, for me, when I was a kid, I think -- the idea was, in my mind, I thought everybody else was having a picnic, but I grew up in a big city and I -- my parents weren't doing that. So, I always thought it would be great to go on a picnic. That would be Americana. The other thing is though -- so when I got married, I got married on July 1st, and so on July 4th, we didn't go on our honeymoon but we're walking around Washington waiting for the fireworks. And I've got to tell you it was great because the crowd comes, people are happy. You talk about a moment of American unity. Everybody celebrates the Fourth of July. I don't care where you are.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Unity goes away of the fifth.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Question six, here we go, this comes from Nancy Coburn, if we travel back to 1776, what would your occupation be? Greg Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I think I'd be a time travel agent because if there were people coming back home I would have to be in charge of making their plans.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You get commission on that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I wonder what the commission would be on that. OK, Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I would like -- Because if I'm being realistic, what job would they have given a woman in 1776 at that time? Probably not -- We're not probably to get to be a scout. I would like to be a scout. I don't know. Probably -- I would hope I would be able to do some sort of writing or teaching or something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You can do public relations. They've had public relations back then.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But they didn't have women doing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I love it. I would be a lawyer. I'm just going to say that I would just force my way in to it, somehow, someway.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: To be a lawyer.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Maybe if I had to like disguise myself, then I would do it. Yeah. That little white wig thing that you put on, and then I would just like.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. Jesse, I have something in mind for you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think that you should go and fight against the British. I think you should be a soldier.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I probably would have been on the British side, though, because those were my people. I would have been a red coat, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And if I was on the British side, we probably would have won. I would be the difference maker. I wanted to think about what I want to do. I wanted to be one of the midnight riders that road with Paul Revere that warned that the British were coming. I think I'd be really good at just yelling on the top of a horse.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Just like Watters' World.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I want to be a cobbler.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You like to touch people's shoes?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know. It just seems that it would be fun to sit around and just hammer on people's feet. Be a cobbler.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: On their feet. I think on the shoes is what you meant.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Feet, shoes, can't tell back then.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Very leathery.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, if the founding fathers are watching via space or psych something, don't be offended. Greg didn't mean it. Coming up, if The Five could solve any mystery, which one would we choose? We're going to tell you next.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: On this Fourth of July, the president and his wife are hosting a barbecue for some military families at the White House. Let's listen in.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: By gunnery sergeant, Sarah Sheffield, from the president's own United States marine band.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: O say, can you see by the dawn's early light. What so proudly we hailed at the twilight's last gleaming whose broad stripes and bright stars through the perilous fight, or the ramparts we watched were so gallantly streaming. And the rockets' red glare, the bombs bursting in air gave proof through the night that our flag was still there. O say, does that star spangled banner yet wave, or the land of the free and the home of the brave.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: Great day.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Melania and I are honored to celebrate American independence with the heroes who protect American independence, the men, the women of the United States military. These are our finest. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Joining us today are two of your biggest fans and strongest supporters, our great Vice President Mike Pence, and his incredible wife, Karen Pence. Thank you, Karen, Mike. We're also honored to be joined by members of my cabinet, secretaries, Alex Azar, Ben Carson, Elaine Chao, Kirstjen Nielsen, Acting Secretary Peter O'Rourke, Administrator Scott Pruitt, and Ambassador Bob Lighthizer. Thank you for being here.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Two hundred and forty two years ago on July 4th, 1776, America's founders adopted the Declaration of Independence and change the course of human history. But our freedom exists only because there are brave Americans willing to give their lives to defend it and defend our great country. American liberty has been earned through the blood, sweat, and sacrifice of American patriots. The immortal story of the American warrior is written in the fields of Gettysburg, the sands of Iwo Jima, the mountains of Afghanistan, and the snow of Valley Forge. It is the story of courage, honor, duty, loyalty, and love. Today, we are honored to recognize a few of the incredible men and women who serve our country and defend our great American flag. From the army, we have retired Captain Jason Pack. Jason is a West Point graduate who was injured in Afghanistan while proudly serving with the second infantry division. Also with us today is Jason's dad, young K, who is also a West Point graduate. And his mom, young A. What an inspiring family. I met them right behind the stage, and I want to tell you their story is an incredible one. Thank you all for your service and thank you for your incredible work for our military and for our country. Thank you very much, Jason. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Representing the navy, we have petty officer first class, Steve Swift. He is a master explosive ordinance disposal technician, and that's a tough job and a dangerous job, also known as the bomb squad. He is a very good technician and has done just incredible work, recently earning distinction as sailor of the quarter for his unit. Joining him are his wife, Crystal, his daughters, Caitlyn and Gwen, and his parents, Catherine and Steven senior. Thank you, Steve, and thank you to everyone serving America in our incredible navy. Thank you. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: From the coast guard, we have Lieutenant Ryan McCue. He is a helicopter pilot who protects all of us here in the capital. One of Ryan's most important jobs is to intercept aircraft that fly where they are not supposed to be flying in and around the capital area. Ryan is assigned to air station Atlantic City, but is temporarily assigned here, away from his wife, Shannon, and son, Colin. They miss him. Ryan, thank you and your family for what you have done and continue to do for all of us. Thank you. Thank you very much, Ryan.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: The men and women of the United States coast guard are doing a phenomenal job keeping America safe from drugs, crime, and terrorism, and we are incredibly grateful to each of you. And I have to say that during the hurricanes, the coast guard saved 16,000 lives. It's an incredible achievement. Incredible. From the air force, we have Captain Brooke Peel. As a weather officer, he leads deployable weather forecasting teams to make it possible for American aviators to own the skies anywhere we fly. He also helped lead the air national guard's response to Hurricane Maria. He did an incredible job. And because of his exceptional leadership, he was named weather company great officer of the year for 2017. Thank you very much. Thank you very much. Incredible.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: And we have the air force, and by the way, I might add, we very well may soon have the space force. You've been hearing about that.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Everyone is very excited about that. I'm also told that Brooke happens to be the reigning champion of his fantasy football league. His sister, Sharla, is with him today, and I want to thank you, Brooke, and I want to thank everybody from the United States air force. Great people and very talented people. Finally, from the marine corps, we have Staff Sergeant Jonathan Grace here with us with his wife, Sidney, and his son, William. A senior analyst for the cyber incident response team, he is one of the very talented people who protect our nation from cyberattacks. And he is very, very good at his craft. In fact, he's done such a great job that they not only asked him to develop a new curriculum on cyber warfare. They also asked him to teach the first class of the newly established cyberspace marines. So, to Jonathan and every American who wears the marine corp. uniform, we are truly grateful. Thank you very much. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: Thank you. To every service member here today and stationed around the world, they're all watching. And to your incredible families, these are truly unbelievable people. Thank you for keeping America safe, strong, proud, mighty, and free. God bless you. God bless our military, and God bless America. Happy Fourth of July. Thank you, everybody. Thank you. Thank you. In the meantime, the minority whip of the House of Representatives is in the hospital. Steny Hoyer has pneumonia. He is expected to recover. Now, we want to take you to New York City where a protester apparently has climbed the pedestal of the Statue of Liberty. You can see there, agents trying to get her down. That's the woman there on the right-hand side of the base of the statue right beneath the heel of the statue's foot. There were other protesters who hung a banner on the statue that said abolish ICE, we assume that this woman is part of that protest group, but that has not been absolutely determined at this point. She climbed the base of the statue, which is quite illegal, as you can imagine. And she's just sitting there as authorities are trying to talk her down or bring her down. You can imagine they have evacuated Liberty Island as a result of that. And a number of people who've been waiting for months, perhaps years to have their chance to see the statue up close and personal and have their vacation plans destroyed as a result of this act. A couple of groups or a couple of members of some kind of anti-ICE group hung a abolish ICE banner on the pedestal of the statue just before this woman climbed onto the statue itself. They're continuing to try to coax the woman down, but not using a great deal of force to do so at this point, apparently, just hoping to wait her out. So, again, this appears to be connected to the protest of the moment which began really just last week when a candidate for congress won a significant primary in the state of New York asking that ICE, the Immigrations and Customs Enforcement agency, be abolished. That mean has caught fire among the left and this group is protesting. Some other headlines, a wildfire burning in Southern Colorado has destroyed more than 100 homes. The spring fire has burned through nearly 100,000 acres making it the third largest wildfire in state history. It is just 5 percent contained. And Ohio congressman, Jim Jordan, is once again denying claims he knew about sexual abuse allegations against a team doctor at the Ohio State University where he was once an assistant coach. Jordan told reporters at a Fourth of July event in Fremont, Ohio, that things some former athletes claim he knew are just not true. Stay with us. We'll be back at the top of the hour with all your headlines on Special Report.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back to The Five. We have a lot of great questions, so let's get to it. Josh Palmer, Facebook, what is your favorite memory of being on The Five? Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I think the buzz trip was probably right up there. There are a lot of memories along that way. But we're trying to figure out -- there's a -- you and I had a situation where we laughed so hard that we cried. That's happened before too. Like early on, especially, Greg would make me laugh so hard and I could not even talk anymore. So, there're very rare instances that work where you get to crack up that much and not get fired.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, we've got paid for laughing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, it was good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Remember the fire?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You had passed out. But I rescued -- I basically rescued all of you and carried you out of studio when we were in Studio D, out into the street. You were unconscious. You probably don't remember this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I blacked out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, you did. Well, you were blackout drunk when it happened.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think I started it. Kimberly. Guilfoyle catches Watters. How many times have I heard that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is so nuts. But I have caught on fire three times. It was not good. Not for the hair. The thing is, I think the favorite memory, I agree with Dana, the bus tour was pretty spectacular. It was great memories, going to the zoo and doing everything like that was super fun. I don't know. There's just so --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Sledding.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, sledding. Oh, you were -- what a ringer, man. She's like an Olympic sledder. Unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I lost, though.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Like Jamaican bobsled team to victory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was it a toboggan? What kind of sled was it?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Just plastic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just plastic?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I got sabotaged in that my pants were too big, and I was trying to like -- remember?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I was trying to pull them up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's your excuse? Your pants? Wardrobe malfunction?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not going to give it to you. Juan, what is your favorite?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: My favorite moment?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: On "The Five," Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know -- you know what I think? It's in between the breaks.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Because so many things get said in the breaks. And I think the audience knows this, by the way.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think they know that there's conversations. But in the break --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Maybe we should start recording them on our phone and putting them out on Twitter.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Exactly. It would be great. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think sometimes things get said in the break, and you're like, "Wow. Whoa, I guess we shouldn't say that." But sometimes we come back, and people are laughing. And then we say, if you only knew what happened in the break.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's a very good answer, actually.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'd have to bleep a lot of that stuff in the breaks. My favorite moment? When I gave Greg a Thighmaster, and it exploded and almost took his face off.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was -- that was incredible. I almost ended up in a major lawsuit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You almost sued the pants off me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But the scissors were pointing towards my eyes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was holding a pair of scissors when that thing -- and the scissors, you could've taken out two hosts.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Two for one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK, wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You have any more? You'd have Diamond and Silk here instead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think when you got your red leather jacket was pretty good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was a great moment.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, that -- you were really excited

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Also, when Beckel gave me the finger. All right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Trump supporter.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Next question, from Twitter, "If granted a foreign citizenship, which country would you choose?" Kimberly Guilfoyle.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, I already have Ireland, though. Let's see.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ireland?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, I don't know. Like, what I want anything else? Maybe Spain.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Spain? That could be nice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Iberian.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Iberian. You are a little Iberian. Juan, what about you?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is going to sound like I'm putting on, but it's the truth. I'm so American. When you go overseas, you know, if you're black, you always think, "Well, I'm in the minority." But then you go overseas, and people are, like, quick to say, you know, "You're an American, aren't you?"

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You really strike me as a real American.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think, even though I'm only 2.2 percent Italian --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Whoa.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- that I would go with Italy.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I feel like you'd get a nice olive complexion. You tan beautifully.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you are very tan right now.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I was 100 percent, but only 2.2 percent Italian.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow, you really bragging about your heritage. Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I would pick Vermont. Vermont. It's a different place out there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- Vermont.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes. And I'm tired of having to bring my passport, so it will be nice to, you know, have the citizenship.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was going to say Mexico, but then I realized I would have to pay for the wall, so I'm going to go with Britain. They still have all the colonies and the pirates. So it might make traveling a lot easier.

utterances.speaker: Next question from Facebook
utterances.utterance: "If you could have back something you lost, what would it be?" Besides your dignity, Greg, what would it be?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Actually, I have a great answer to this, for once. I had a baseball card of Joe DiMaggio --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, when he was with the San Francisco Seals --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- which is a minor league ball club --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- in San Francisco. I had -- it was my dad's. I had it in my wallet, and I lost my wallet in college.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: How much would that be worth?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It wasn't in great quality. But it would have been something.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Huge.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a big one. I like that one. Dana, what about you?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was a big one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think I haven't completely lost it. I think it is somewhere. But it was my great-grandmother's wedding band, and I got married in it. It's simple gold wedding band.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Where is it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's in what -- it's in a box in a trunk somewhere. I mean, we've moved so many times that I don't think I've lost it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Are you anxious about this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, it just started up again.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You're making me feel anxious about it. But I'd be afraid to almost go look and check the trunk, because if it's not there, you'd be very upset. It's almost better to believe it's there and not somewhere --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's what I'm saying. I think it's there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Have Peter look into it. Kimberly, what about you? What have you lost?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What do I want back? Well --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What do you want back?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. So two things, actually. Can I just say, I actually think about this. And I thought about it the other day. I had this little ball. It was so cute. And it had all these stars and stuff on it. And I used to play with it all the time. And I was playing out in the street, played with my friends, and then it went, it rolled down the gutter in the sewer, the grate thing or whatever. And I was, like, looking at it in there, and I was like, crying. My dad had come home from work and, like, tried to lift the thing out to get it. It was, like, a whole situation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That was from the movie "It," Kimberly. Really.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Was it really? That was real. And then the other thing, which I talked about on the show, and then someone sent me a beautiful Winnie the Pooh doll, because I had it. It was what my mom gave it to me before she passed away at, and then my dad gave away all my stuffed animals. And Winnie the Pooh was in it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's very sentimental. You've got to get that back. Put a Pooh alert out there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know, it's -- I don't know who has it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We'll look into it. Maybe it's in a box with the ring.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: FOX News alert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think I'd take my hair back.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Me, too.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, because I'm balding in the back. I'm, like, nobody -- people say to me, what are you getting uptight about? I just don't know. Imagine, when I was a kid, I had a fro, man.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We need to see pictures of that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And I mean, when I went off to school, people would say, you know, you look like, you know, a daisy or something with this fro. You know, what do they call those flowers?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dandelions.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Dandelion, I'd look like a dandelion, because I would have on purple cons (ph) and a fro. Skinny as a rail.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but you -- you have very good hair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We need those pictures stat.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You look very young. The pictures of you even 20 years ago, you look the same.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're very kind.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Way to butter him up, K.G.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, it is true.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Next question. If you could have any other job. All right. You know what? We're going to save that for the next Fourth of July. There's nothing better than a good summer anthem. Up next, our favorite songs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Welcome back to "The Five" Fourth of July fan mail special. Time to answer more of your questions. All right. These are from Facebook. Is there a song that reminds you of summer whenever you hear it? I have one, but I'll save mine till last. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Gutfeld is going to make fun of me. I'm going to go with Don Henley, "Boys of Summer." Is that too --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- easy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know, but it's obvious, and I love it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Did it come out in the summertime?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. But it's -- you know. How does it go again?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's confusing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I just lost about 1,000 viewers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Pretty good, pretty good. Kimberly, do you have a song that you remember? Kimberly's song.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I love the Will Smith song, what is it? Like, "Summertime."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS (singing)
utterances.utterance: "Summertime, Summertime."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean, I've got to keep up with these guys. So "Summertime," "Porgy and Bess." That's a pretty good song.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But you know what I really like for just driving down the street is James Brown, "Living in America." Super highway --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Love it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, those are fun.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, I'm going to say it's more -- The Outfield. And they had a song called, "I Don't Want to Lose Your Love Tonight."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I love that song.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It must have been -- I was 16 and I had a car, a driver's license. My birthdays in May, so I had a car for the whole summer. And my sister and I would turn it up, and I would listen to that. Ever since, anytime I hear that song, even if it's in the middle of winter, I think of summer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Great song.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Your turn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a different way of looking at it. It doesn't have to have the word "summer" in it. You know, because if I picked the -- I would have to say AC/DC, "Highway to Hell." Because there was a summertime where, when we would go through San Mateo to Santa Cruz to the beach, and we'd all be packed in the car and we'd just be listening to that album, "Highway to Hell" by AC/DC --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That's the perfect atheist summer song.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I guess it had to be '81 or '82. But that was -- that was the album. No, I'm talking about high school friends, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So you would just play it over and over?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. And then the Sex Pistols on the way back. Because you know, you had to have both.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You absolutely did. All right. So then, let me ask you this. What is your favorite Fourth of July movie? Do you have one, K.G.?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, yes, I do. I would say "Top Gun." I really like that. I think it's very patriotic. Love the military. Love dudes playing volleyball.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That was pretty good. And they're remaking it, too. "Top Gun 2" is coming out soon. Jesse, do you have a movie?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was going to say "Last of the Mohicans." I like the music. Good score. Good score on that one. But also very patriotic there. Daniel Day-Lewis.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, I appreciate that on behalf of my people.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Six percent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right, six percent.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Six percent. It's easy for me, "Independence Day." Because, you know, they're going off and the president is leading American military as we're shooting down the aliens that are coming to invade the planet Earth. And so the U.S. takes the lead. No isolationism. No unilateral --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Was Will Smith president?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm trying to remember the one. If they build it, they will come. If you build it, they will come. "Field of Dreams."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: "Field of Dreams," Kevin Costner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I went to see it on the Fourth of July.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's cool.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Greg, movie.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jeez. I guess the big favorite for July 4th at the Gutfeld house was "It's a Wonderful Life."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes. Play it all year long.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: July 4.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Do you leave your lights up, too, all year?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right. Rose wine is a popular summer drink. No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Rose?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Rose wine is a popular summer drink, but what's our cocktail of choice? That's up next when July 4th's fan mail special continues.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So welcome back to "The Five." We're answering more of your fan mail questions on this Independence Day. All right. So first question, Instagram from @MomsCoffee. "What is your favorite summertime cocktail," folks. All right. Greg, we'll start with you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't have a favorite. I don't have a favorite.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I thought you had, like, the Moscow Mule or something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, I don't like that, because I like Dark and Stormy. But you know, I don't like to play favorites. They're all equally wonderful in my book.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You do like a good Dark and Stormy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You tend to get a little inebriated quickly on that. I think you have better pacing with red wine, with pinot noir. Just my observation. Thank you. OK, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't really drink any hard liquor, but I like -- if I have a rose or a white wine spritzer. A lot of ice.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: By the way, that's a good idea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know how to take risks.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Slow it down. I slow it way down.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: She's a risk taker, all right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Last call, last call. Spritzer for the lady.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Living on the wild side.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I remember what happened. The port, oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's because you had been drinking and then you finished off with port at the end of the night, and that did you in.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Don't ever do that.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: She was not well. Five a.m. in the morning. It was not good. All right. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last summer was Moscow Mules. This summer is gin and tonic. Hendrick's gin, of course.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Indeed, indeed. That's very popular.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very sophisticated of you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what people think of when they look at me.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Gin drinkers love Hendrick's.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, they do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It has a wonderful bouquet. I would say I like gin and tonics, but summertime is pina colada time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Ooh, I change mine now. I love pina drinks by the pool.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, really.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Great song. We should have picked that one.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Got to have an umbrella in the cup.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Only the best for me, Greg. Keep them coming. The girlier the better.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, so let's see. I think just -- for me, I love anything with, like, you know, tequila in it. A really good margarita or just tequila soda. I think it's, like, crisp and clean. A little bit of -- mmm-mm.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Frozen margarita or regular?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I tend to go margarita, rocks, no salt.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No salt?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, because I get my salt in my chips and salsa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, you've got it all figured out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I really do. And I have, you know, a way to execute this, and it's really worked out well for me. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go gym teacher, and we played Dodgeball to the Death. Old-school. It sure has.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, fine. Facebook question from Terry L., "If you could be a teacher in high school for one day, what subject would you teach and why?" Mr. Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: English. I love it. You know, it's interesting, because I was a philosophy major in college, and I sometimes look back and I think "Why didn't I do political science? Why didn't I do history? Things like that?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What about history?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: yes. I think English is so much fun. You can get into all kinds of stories and books and take people to different worlds. I love it.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was a nice answer and you had a lot of enthusiasm. Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm going to go with gym teacher. And we'd play dodgeball to the death. Old school.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: This is so predictable. You know people are upset with that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Until they cry. Head shots allowed.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'd do life skills.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What a freak.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: For one day in a high school, life skills.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Minute mentoring.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's probably -- that's useful.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: OK, Greg. Quick.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Obviously, it would be Gutfeld 101. And the books would be "The Gutfeld Monologues."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There it is.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's available at Amazon.com. It will be out soon, but order it now, because supplies are limited. Then you'd have "The Joy of Hate." You'd have "Not Cool." You'd have all my books. "The Bible of Unspeakable Truths." Any books I left out?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Unbelievable self-promoter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "How to Be Right."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Enough of you. I would love to -- I taught high school, but I was probably too young to be teaching high school. So that was a little bit interesting. But I loved teaching and working with special needs kids. And that's what my mom did, and I did that, as well. And so -- I would do that in high school and just work with them. It was very rewarding. All right. One more question next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. It's time for one last question. This is from Instagram, @pamela.dowdy.75 asks: "What do you think makes America a great country?" Let's start with the patriot, Jesse Watters.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I would say the American spirit. The way we're always renewing ourselves and reinventing ourselves and pushing further and further the limits. Also our geography. The fact that we're separated by two oceans, and just gives us such a natural advantage over our enemies. And all the natural resources we have, the diversity of them really makes us the greatest nation ever.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Ever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In the history of the world.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: There we go. To our first lady.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So I would say our American military. I really feel very patriotic about the military, and the men and women that serve and so that we can all enjoy our freedoms. And they also help out in times of need and distress. Like, Marines going out and helping with people, in terms of humanitarian efforts in rebuilding areas that have been ravaged through tragedy and suffering. So you see some of the kind effects done by the United States military overseas and with children and everything. It's very sweet.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And our own Betsy Ross.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would say the founding principles. So the Constitution, and the whole principle of how our country came together. Our Founding Fathers were so wise, and they were very young, actually. They were sort of, like, in their mid-30s, and they wrote a Constitution that has held up over these 200-odd years. And so I think that the fact that it's based on liberty, which is everyone's natural state of being, the desire to be free, that you actually get to have that here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And now for a dissenting point, King George.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'd have to say the shopping. The shopping in America is great. You can get just about anything you want and at a decent price, and you can have it delivered to you almost at any time of the day. America, it's where the world shops.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: You like that with food, too. You're always ordering.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Definitely.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Never have to leave your apartment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Never have to leave your apartment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And your apartment is bigger than anybody else's.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, so --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: America.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? Your answers are so ordinary to me. Because literally, as an immigrant kid, I've got to tell you, the United States is special and wonderful because it's stable. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I mean, you have political freedoms. For now. I thought you liked Trump. What's going on here? But I mean, political freedoms. Economic stability, economic opportunity. Wow, I think this is a great country. I mean, like, fireworks. They should have fireworks to celebrate this country.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's just getting better.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think we're on our way. I think so.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Juan thinks it's a great country. I want everybody to know this was July 4, 2018. Juan said it. We're going to hold you to that now, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can hold to me any day of the year.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right, good.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I actually think it is a great country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Although I think there are some people who are up to sneaky business.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, like Strzok and page.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh. You know, we never stop with the fireworks. That's it for this special edition of "The Five." You know, we hope all of you have a wonderful Independence Day. We're going to see you back here tomorrow. Don't miss it. And guess what? "Special Report" up next. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
